section.title: Introduction
section.t: Both Parallel Network File System (pNFS) and the File Layout Type were defined in the Network File System (NFS) version 4.1 protocol specification, . The Block Layout Type was defined in and the Object Layout Type was in turn defined in .

Some implementors have interpretted the text in Sections 12 ("Parallel NFS (pNFS)") and 13 ("NFSv4.1 as a Storage Protocol in pNFS: the File Layout Type") of as both being strictly for the File Layout Type. I.e., since Section 13 was not covered in a separate RFC like those for both the Block and Object Layout Types, there is some confusion as to the responsibilities of both the Metadata Server (MDS) and the Data Servers (DS).
As a consequence, new internet drafts (see and ) may not be meeting the requirements to be a pNFS Layout Type.

list.t: is one of the pNFS servers which provide the contents of a file system object which is a regular file. Depending on the layout, there might be one or more DSes over which the data is striped. Note that while the MDS is strictly accessed over the NFSv4.1 protocol, depending on the Layout Type, the DS could be accessed via any protocol that meets the pNFS requirements.
is a description of how a file's data is organized on one or more storage devices.

is a 128-bit quantity returned by a server that uniquely defines the layout state provided by the server for a specific layout that describes a Layout Type and file (see Section 12.5.2 of ). Further, Section 12.5.3 describes the difference between a layout stateid and a normal stateid.
describes both the storage protocol used to access the data and the aggregation scheme used to lays out the file data on the underlying storage devices.
is that part of the file system object which describes the object and not the payload. E.g., it could be the time since last modification, access, etc.
is the pNFS server which provides metadata information for a file system object. It also is repsonsible for generating layouts for file system objects.

is a 128-bit quantity returned by a server that uniquely defines the open and locking states provided by the server for a specific open-owner or lock-owner/open-owner pair for a specific file and type of lock.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .
